articles.headline: Out Sick for the Enron Trial, and Rethinking It
articles.snippet: Michael W. Ramsey, the lead lawyer for Kenneth L. Lay, missed more than a month of the 56-day Enron trial because of heart complications.
articles.abstract: Michael W. Ramsey, the lead lawyer for Kenneth L. Lay, missed more than a month of the 56-day Enron trial because of heart complications.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, May 18 — It started with what felt like a heart attack.

articles.headline: As Death Stalks Iraq, Middle-Class Exodus Begins
articles.snippet: Increasing portions of the middle class seem to be doing everything they can to leave Iraq.
articles.abstract: Increasing portions of the middle class seem to be doing everything they can to leave Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 18 — Deaths run like water through the life of the Bahjat family. Four neighbors. A barber. Three grocers. Two men who ran a currency exchange shop.

articles.headline: Apple, a Success at Stores, Bets Big on Fifth Avenue
articles.snippet: Since it opened its first two stores five years ago today, the Apple chain has become a retailing phenomenon.
articles.abstract: Since it opened its first two stores five years ago today, the Apple chain has become a retailing phenomenon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after Ron Johnson joined Apple Computer in 2000, his new boss, Steven P. Jobs, summoned him to a room at the company headquarters. Mr. Jobs, Apple's chief executive and impresario, pointed to a conference table with just four computers on it.

articles.headline: What Fraud? All Was Fine at Enron
articles.snippet: Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling went for the "nothing happened" defense, holding that there was nothing really wrong until Enron folded because of a loss of confidence.
articles.abstract: Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling went for the "nothing happened" defense, holding that there was nothing really wrong until Enron folded because of a loss of confidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT was not much of a defense. But I was very young and had little time to decide what to say.

articles.headline: Iran's Secrecy Widens Gap in Nuclear Intelligence
articles.snippet: Limits on inspections have restricted the world's ability to answer questions about Iran's nuclear ambitions.
articles.abstract: Limits on inspections have restricted the world's ability to answer questions about Iran's nuclear ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and Elaine Sciolino

articles.headline: Dell to Use Chip Made by A.M.D.
articles.snippet: Dell, which has used only Intel processors until now, announced the move as part of a broader plan to improve its flagging sales and market share.
articles.abstract: Dell, which has used only Intel processors until now, announced the move as part of a broader plan to improve its flagging sales and market share.

articles.headline: Violent Rebel Rift Adds Layer to Darfur's Misery
articles.snippet: Two of the main rebel factions fighting the Sudanese government have turned on each other in a grisly battle.
articles.abstract: Two of the main rebel factions fighting the Sudanese government have turned on each other in a grisly battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: TINA, Sudan, May 16 — A grisly new battle between rebel factions is raging here in Darfur, casting doubts on the future of a peace agreement to end the war.

articles.headline: Japanese Cars, American Retirees
articles.snippet: Japanese automakers put health and pension burdens squarely on the workers, a distinct advantage over their American counterparts.
articles.abstract: Japanese automakers put health and pension burdens squarely on the workers, a distinct advantage over their American counterparts.
articles.lead_paragraph: GEORGETOWN, Ky. — For the last quarter-century, Toyota, Honda and Nissan have strived to appear to American consumers like homegrown companies.

articles.headline: U.S. Indictment for Big Law Firm in Class Actions
articles.snippet: Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman was accused of paying clients to sue in securities cases.
articles.abstract: Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman was accused of paying clients to sue in securities cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation's leading class-action securities law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, and two of its partners were charged yesterday with making more than $11 million in secret payments to three individuals who served as plaintiffs in more than 150 lawsuits.

articles.headline: U.S. Indictment for Big Law Firm in Class Actions
articles.snippet: The nation's leading class-action securities law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, and two of its partners were charged yesterday with making more than $11 million in secret payments to three individuals who served as plaintiffs in more than...
articles.abstract: The nation's leading class-action securities law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, and two of its partners were charged yesterday with making more than $11 million in secret payments to three individuals who served as plaintiffs in more than 150 lawsuits.     The indictment is the first instance of a law firm with national reach facing criminal charges, and it could prove to be a fatal blow for the firm. The lawsuits cited in the indictment spanned two decades, occurring as recently as 2005, and generated some $216 million in legal fees for the firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation's leading class-action securities law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, and two of its partners were charged yesterday with making more than $11 million in secret payments to three individuals who served as plaintiffs in more than 150 lawsuits.

articles.headline: Violent Rebel Rift Adds Layer to Darfur's Misery
articles.snippet: A grisly new battle between rebel factions is raging here in Darfur, casting doubts on the future of a peace agreement to end the war.      Two of the main rebel factions fighting the Sudanese government and its allied militias have turned on each...
articles.abstract: A grisly new battle between rebel factions is raging here in Darfur, casting doubts on the future of a peace agreement to end the war.      Two of the main rebel factions fighting the Sudanese government and its allied militias have turned on each other, spurred by ethnic tensions and what appears to be a relentless grab for more territory. Now the rebels have unleashed a tide of violence against the very civilians they once joined forces to protect.
articles.lead_paragraph: TINA, Sudan, May 16 - A grisly new battle between rebel factions is raging here in Darfur, casting doubts on the future of a peace agreement to end the war.

articles.headline: Out Sick for the Enron Trial, and Rethinking It
articles.snippet: It started with what felt like a heart attack.     Just minutes after he had cross-examined Enron's former chief financial officer two months ago, Michael W. Ramsey, the lead lawyer for Kenneth L. Lay, turned to one of Mr. Lay's daughters. ''I thi...
articles.abstract: It started with what felt like a heart attack.     Just minutes after he had cross-examined Enron's former chief financial officer two months ago, Michael W. Ramsey, the lead lawyer for Kenneth L. Lay, turned to one of Mr. Lay's daughters. ''I think I just had a heart attack,'' he half-jokingly told the daughter, Elizabeth Vittor, looking her in the eye across the defense table.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, May 18 - It started with what felt like a heart attack.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Choice Says He's Independent of the Pentagon
articles.snippet: Gen. Michael V. Hayden sought on Thursday to distance himself from the Pentagon and its role in prewar intelligence on Iraq, in an appearance that put him on track to win swift confirmation as the next director of the Central Intelligence Agency. ...
articles.abstract: Gen. Michael V. Hayden sought on Thursday to distance himself from the Pentagon and its role in prewar intelligence on Iraq, in an appearance that put him on track to win swift confirmation as the next director of the Central Intelligence Agency.      In a confirmation hearing before the Senate Intelligence Committee, General Hayden appeared in the pristine blue uniform he has worn for 36 years as an Air Force officer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 18 - Gen. Michael V. Hayden sought on Thursday to distance himself from the Pentagon and its role in prewar intelligence on Iraq, in an appearance that put him on track to win swift confirmation as the next director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

articles.headline: Japanese Cars, American Retirees
articles.snippet: For the last quarter-century, Toyota, Honda and Nissan have strived to appear to American consumers like homegrown companies.      They built a string of manufacturing plants in the South, employing tens of thousands of local workers. They hired A...
articles.abstract: For the last quarter-century, Toyota, Honda and Nissan have strived to appear to American consumers like homegrown companies.      They built a string of manufacturing plants in the South, employing tens of thousands of local workers. They hired American designers. They spent millions on ads to trumpet their growing roots in communities across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: GEORGETOWN, Ky. - For the last quarter-century, Toyota, Honda and Nissan have strived to appear to American consumers like homegrown companies.

articles.headline: Apple, a Success at Stores, Bets Big on Fifth Avenue
articles.snippet: Shortly after Ron Johnson joined Apple Computer in 2000, his new boss, Steven P. Jobs, summoned him to a room at the company headquarters. Mr. Jobs, Apple's chief executive and impresario, pointed to a conference table with just four computers on ...
articles.abstract: Shortly after Ron Johnson joined Apple Computer in 2000, his new boss, Steven P. Jobs, summoned him to a room at the company headquarters. Mr. Jobs, Apple's chief executive and impresario, pointed to a conference table with just four computers on it.      ''Here's our products,'' Mr. Johnson remembers Mr. Jobs telling him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after Ron Johnson joined Apple Computer in 2000, his new boss, Steven P. Jobs, summoned him to a room at the company headquarters. Mr. Jobs, Apple's chief executive and impresario, pointed to a conference table with just four computers on it.

articles.headline: Dell to Use Chip Made by A.M.D.
articles.snippet: Dell, which has used only Intel processors until now, announced yesterday that it would begin using a chip made by Advanced Micro Devices, as part of a broader plan to improve its flagging sales and market share.     Dell said that by the end of t...
articles.abstract: Dell, which has used only Intel processors until now, announced yesterday that it would begin using a chip made by Advanced Micro Devices, as part of a broader plan to improve its flagging sales and market share.     Dell said that by the end of the year, it would start using an A.M.D. Opteron chip in one of its high-end servers with multiple processors. ''It's a fairly small category,'' Kevin B. Rollins, chief executive of Dell, said on a conference call with analysts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Iran's Secrecy Widens Gap in Nuclear Intelligence
articles.snippet: South of Tehran, the desert gives way to barbed wire, antiaircraft guns and a maze of buildings, two of them cavernous underground halls roughly half the size of the Pentagon.     International inspectors could once roam the 20 or so main building...
articles.abstract: South of Tehran, the desert gives way to barbed wire, antiaircraft guns and a maze of buildings, two of them cavernous underground halls roughly half the size of the Pentagon.     International inspectors could once roam the 20 or so main buildings there, at the Natanz uranium enrichment complex. Operating more like detectives than scientists, they combined painstaking sleuthing with physics and engineering in an effort to ascertain the site's true mission, war or peace.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and Elaine Sciolino

articles.headline: What Fraud? All Was Fine at Enron
articles.snippet: IT was not much of a defense. But I was very young and had little time to decide what to say.     I had violated the rules by sneaking ice cream from the freezer. The carton had slipped and split open on the floor, making a mess and a noise that m...
articles.abstract: IT was not much of a defense. But I was very young and had little time to decide what to say.     I had violated the rules by sneaking ice cream from the freezer. The carton had slipped and split open on the floor, making a mess and a noise that my mother investigated.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT was not much of a defense. But I was very young and had little time to decide what to say.

articles.headline: Vote in House Seeks to Erase Oil Windfall
articles.snippet: In an attempt to revoke billions of dollars worth of government incentives to oil and gas producers, the House on Thursday approved a measure that would pressure companies to renegotiate more than 1,000 leases for drilling in the Gulf of Mexico.  ...
articles.abstract: In an attempt to revoke billions of dollars worth of government incentives to oil and gas producers, the House on Thursday approved a measure that would pressure companies to renegotiate more than 1,000 leases for drilling in the Gulf of Mexico.     The measure, approved 252 to 165 over the objections of many Republican leaders, is intended to prevent companies from avoiding at least $7 billion in payments to the government over the next five years for oil and gas they produce in publicly owned waters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: As Death Stalks Iraq, Middle-Class Exodus Begins
articles.snippet: Deaths run like water through the life of the Bahjat family. Four neighbors. A barber. Three grocers. Two men who ran a currency exchange shop.     But when six armed men stormed into their sons' primary school this month, shot a guard dead, and l...
articles.abstract: Deaths run like water through the life of the Bahjat family. Four neighbors. A barber. Three grocers. Two men who ran a currency exchange shop.     But when six armed men stormed into their sons' primary school this month, shot a guard dead, and left fliers ordering it to close, Assad Bahjat knew it was time to leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 18 - Deaths run like water through the life of the Bahjat family. Four neighbors. A barber. Three grocers. Two men who ran a currency exchange shop.
